document.discussion_title: 2014 Napa earthquake continued to creep, weeks after main shock
document.topic_text: Terra Daily Monday 22nd August, 2016 Nearly two years ago, on August 24, 2014, just south of Napa, California, a fault in the Earth suddenly slipped, violently shifting and splitting huge blocks of solid rock, 6 miles below the surface. The underground upheaval generated severe shaking at the surface, lasting 10 to 20 seconds. When the shaking subsided, the magnitude 6.0 earthquake - the largest in the San Francisco Bay Area since 1989 - left in its wake crumpled building facades, ruptured water mains, and fractured roadways. But the earthquake wasn't quite done. In a new report, scientists from MIT and elsewhere detail...
